newsitem.title: UK: Huge rise found in antidepressant use - survey.
newsitem.headline: Huge rise found in antidepressant use - survey.

text.p: There has been a huge increase in the use of antidepressants across Britain, mostly due to the popularity of Prozac, researchers reported on Friday.
Dr Richard Martin of St George's Hospital in London and colleagues did regular surveys of 250 doctors and found use of antidepressants shot up 116 percent between 1990 and 1995.
Use of a new class of drugs known as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), led by Eli Lilly and Co's Prozac, rose by 732 percent.

"Overall, antidepressant inceptions (new prescriptions) increased by 116 percent between 1990 and 1995 and serotonin reuptake inhibitor inceptions rose by 732 percent," they wrote in a report in the British Medical Journal.

"In 1995 fluoxetine (Prozac) had the highest share of new prescriptions for antidepressants (24 percent) whereas the market share for 'newer' tricyclic antidepressants (lofepramine and dothiepin) had decreased by 39 percent from 1990 levels." Another SSRI, paroxetine (SmithKline Beecham's Paxil) had a 15 percent share of new prescriptions in 1995.
They said their findings mirrored what happened in the United States 10 years ago.
"The active marketing of serotonin reuptake inhibitors is an important factor in their widespread adoption," they commented.
The increase could be a burden to Britain's National Health Service because the drugs are expensive, Martin's group added.
